text:
Hey braintrusts! 

:loud_sound: So here’s a quick question for you all (long story alert!) 

I joined a scale-up 6 months ago as a Content Marketing Manager and am now due for my probation assessment. 

All in all it has been a wonderful working relationship on both sides. Not to blow my own toot, but based on my Manager’s feedback (who also happens to be the CMO and the Co-founder) it seems that I have checked all the boxes and the management is really happy with what I have achieved. 

The issue is that a LOT has changed since I have joined wrt to the scope of work and handling responsibilities. For example:  

• I’m single handedly responsible for not just overall content marketing, but also website SEO management, digital PR as well as social media. In my last role these were three separate positions. The company had a relationship with an external PR agency but not anymore, so this tells me that there’s budget. 
• My role has evolved into a team management role where I manage one internal employee and have been provided budget to work with other freelancers. 
Given the scenario I’m tempted to ask for more $$$ (the original plan was to bump my CTC by $5000 on successful completion of probation) but that doesn’t seem to justify the pay for the amount of work there is.

I’m also keen on realigning my designation which seems to be the case for others in my team. How do I approach this while not sounding like a douchebag? I really like working here, am not looking out, but the thought that others around me are getting paid more and have a better designation for almost the same amount of work demotivates me.

Thanks for reading! Looking forward to your feedback :woman-cartwheeling::skin-tone-5:

text:
Honestly, I think the way you've laid it out here is exactly how you approach it. If you can paint the picture in terms of the impact/results you're having that would also help tremendously.

Additionally, I would advocate for a junior to take some of the social stuff off your plate. Show them what you have to say "no" to today because you're saying “yes” to this pretty huge mandate and cannot go as deep as you would like.

Lastly, don't be afraid of sounding like a douchebag—you sound totally reasonable!! I'm sure they'd rather hear this now than in an exit interview. Worst case scenario, they say "no" and then you know... the market is hot; you hold all the cards imo.

The way you handle this is with action.

The average person who explain the situation and ask the manager to fix it (figure out the new job description/title/salary). 

You can set yourself apart by coming to your manager with a well-researched documented job description, title, and salary … based on data/results so far. Can you show that you are impacting revenue?

<@UL2E0QVB3> +1 on what <@U027RNU0A69> said. I've literally just followed what she's outlined and have a chat with my manager this week discussing my role.

I got to this point by presenting a slide to our senior leadership team showing our organic presence and how it needs more investment. I've also shared a job description explaining what role I'm suited for including which duties/responsibilities should be removed to unlock stronger results. The JD also includes my salary expectations, because I'm asking for a marketplace adjustment for a new role—numbers are backed by research (Superpath's latest salary report and links to live job ads offering my requested salary).

Check out the SEO MBA for more information on communicating at the exec level and securing buy in. Don't shy away from presenting data-backed wins you've achieved.
